results.title: Who protects the consumer?
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Free to choose”.
Milton Friedman disputes the view that consumers need governmental protection against the business community and that government actions tend to make consumers better off. The best protection, he claims, is the free market where consumers will desert inferior products or sevices. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: From cradle to grave
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Free to choose”.
Milton Friedman examines government spending, claiming that it leads to fraud and abuse and may not help the very people it sets out to assist. Self-help projects will, he claims, generate work and lead to a more efficient and dynamic system than the Welfare State can provide. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: The Motion picture and social change
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Ott and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frank Capra: the man above the title”.
A film about Capra’s preoccupation with films that depict social change. He talks about his ambitions and personal politics as reflected in many of his films.

results.title: The Motion picture in persuasion
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Ott and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frank Capra: the man above the title”.
Based on Frank Capra’s book this documentary shows Capra’s involvement with the ‘Why We Fight’ series of World War Two. Capra reflects upon the use of film for overt ideological persuasion. Includes archival footage and excerpts from “Meet John Doe” and “It Happened One Night”.

results.title: Blue collar blues
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
The film through interviews, discusses the problems of automation and the alternatives. The contrast is shown between a Ford factory where the assembly line was devised sixty years ago, the fastest car factory in the world - the General Motors plant in Ohio, the Volvo plant in Sweden, and an Avon factory in Sydney. No other credits available.

results.title: Cancer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Discusses the nature of cancer cells, and how they are identified. Stresses the importance of early diagnosis and prompt treatment in the cure of many cases. Shows the method of self-examination of the breasts; emphasises the need for women to have regular cell tests for uterine cancer; and the value of regular chest X-rays. Shows the work done by the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, the Cytology Service at Prince Henry’s Hospital and the Peter MacCallum Clinic.

results.title: H.M.A.S. Voyager: the cruel legacy
results.creator_credit: Harvey Broadbent and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
On February 10th, 1964, the destroyer HMAS Voyager was sliced in two when it collided with her flagship aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne in Jervis Bay, off the coast of New South Wales. Voyager sunk with the loss of 82 men. This program attempts to piece together the final minutes before the fatal collision and the years of bitter neglect for the survivors of Voyager who are still fighting for justice and compensation. Their burden has been one of broken careers, sometimes broken marriages and often broken mental and physical health. Although two Royal Commissions have taken place, responsibility for the collision still remains unanswered, counselling and support have never been provided to the survivors and a certain amount of suspicion still exists about high-ranking naval personnel cover-ups. Reporter: Andrew Olle.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
On February 10th, 1964, the destroyer HMAS Voyager was sliced in two when it collided with her flagship aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne in Jervis Bay, off the coast of New South Wales. Voyager sunk with the loss of 82 men. This program attempts to piece together the final minutes before the fatal collision and the years of bitter neglect for the survivors of Voyager who are still fighting for justice and compensation. Their burden has been one of broken careers, sometimes broken marriages and often broken mental and physical health. Although two Royal Commissions have taken place, responsibility for the collision still remains unanswered, counselling and support have never been provided to the survivors and a certain amount of suspicion still exists about high-ranking naval personnel cover-ups. Reporter: Andrew Olle.

This program attempts to piece together the final minutes before the fatal collision and the years of bitter neglect for the survivors of Voyager who are still fighting for justice and compensation. Their burden has been one of broken careers, sometimes broken marriages and often broken mental and physical health. Although two Royal Commissions have taken place, responsibility for the collision still remains unanswered, counselling and support have never been provided to the survivors and a certain amount of suspicion still exists about high-ranking naval personnel cover-ups. Reporter: Andrew Olle.
